content.title: About Diwali
content.text: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is the Hindu festival of lights celebrated every year. It symbolizes the spiritual victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

content.title: History and Significance
content.text: Diwali commemorates Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya after defeating Ravana and completing his 14-year exile. People light diyas (oil lamps) to celebrate his return and to honor the goddess of wealth, Lakshmi.

content.title: Celebrations
content.text: The celebration includes lighting diyas and candles, creating rangoli (colorful art patterns), bursting crackers, exchanging gifts and sweets, and performing prayers to Goddess Lakshmi and Lord Ganesha.

content.title: When is it celebrated?
content.text: Diwali is celebrated on the darkest night (new moon) in the month of Kartik according to the Hindu calendar, which typically falls between mid-October and mid-November in the Gregorian calendar.

content.title: Duration
content.text: Diwali is actually a five-day festival, with the main celebrations happening on the third day. Each day has its own significance and rituals.

content.title: About Holi
content.text: Holi is a popular ancient Hindu festival, also known as the 'festival of colors', the 'festival of love', and the 'festival of spring'. It celebrates the eternal and divine love of Radha and Krishna.

content.title: History and Significance
content.text: Holi signifies the triumph of good over evil and the arrival of spring. It is associated with the legend of Holika and Prahlad, where Holika's attempt to burn Prahlad (a devotee of Lord Vishnu) failed, and she was burned instead.

content.title: Celebrations
content.text: The festival begins with Holika Dahan, where people gather around a bonfire. The next day, known as Rangwali Holi, people play with colors, drenching each other in colored water and applying colored powder (gulal). Traditional sweets like gujiya are shared.

content.title: When is it celebrated?
content.text: Holi is celebrated at the approach of the vernal equinox, on the Phalguna Purnima (Full Moon) according to the Hindu calendar, which usually falls in March in the Gregorian calendar.

content.title: Regional Variations
content.text: Holi has different names and traditions across India. In West Bengal it's called 'Dol Jatra', in Assam it's 'Phakuwa', and in Bihar the festival is called 'Phaguwa'.

content.title: About Harvest Festivals
content.text: India celebrates various harvest festivals across different states, marking the season when crops are harvested and farmers express gratitude for a good yield. These festivals honor the connection between nature, agriculture, and human life.

content.title: Regional Variations
content.text: The harvest festival is known by different names across India: Uttarayan in Gujarat, Pongal in Tamil Nadu, Magh Bihu in Assam, and Lohri in Punjab. Each has unique customs but shares the common theme of thanksgiving.

content.title: Celebrations
content.text: Common celebrations include preparing special foods from newly harvested crops, flying kites (especially in Gujarat), lighting bonfires (during Lohri), preparing sweet rice dishes (during Pongal), and folk dances that symbolize joy and prosperity.

content.title: When are they celebrated?
content.text: Most Indian harvest festivals are celebrated in mid-January when the winter crop is harvested. The exact dates may vary according to the solar calendar and regional customs.

content.title: Cultural Significance
content.text: These festivals mark the end of the winter solstice and honor the Sun God for providing energy for crops to grow. They also celebrate community bonds and the agricultural heritage of India.
